awd_titl_txt: Toward a Cryogenic Interferometer for Gravitational-Wave Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the development of instrumentation for future gravitational wave detectors and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. The goal of this project is to make a big leap in gravitational-wave (GW) and measurement science. Gravitational-waves are the newest way to make observations about the universe. They provide the best information about the extremely warped space and time around black holes, exotic neutron stars, and, within the next decade, a unique probe of the expansion of the universe over the last several billion years. Gravitational-waves can be thought of as the audio soundtrack to the movie of the cosmos that humanity has been watching for many years with our telescopes. To measure gravitational-waves, scientists have developed the most sensitive vibration measurement technology in history. The work proposed here aims to push beyond the usual measurement limits of quantum physics and molecular vibrations and produce a novel way of making even more sensitive measurements. In addition to the improvement in astrophysical sensitivity, such measurement science breakthroughs can be used to dramatically improve sensors in hand-held devices and consumer products. 

Gravitational-wave detectors provide the best information about the extremely warped spacetime around black holes, exotic nuclear matter in neutron stars, and, within the next decade, a unique probe of cosmology at high redshifts. The current LIGO detectors will approach the thermodynamic and quantum mechanical limits of their designs within a few years. This project will develop high precision techniques to extend the astrophysical reach by a factor of 5. To do so, Brownian thermal noise will be suppressed by a novel combination of cryogenics and materials science. Quantum backaction and squeezed light will be exploited to surpass the usual quantum limits of interferometry. Such a dramatic change in the sensitivity should increase the detection rate of binary neutron star mergers to ~10/day and the rate of binary black hole mergers to ~30/day. This upgraded instrument would be able to detect binary black holes out to a redshift of 8.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary:

Gravitational waves (GWs), ripples in spacetime caused by cataclysmic cosmic events, offer a new frontier in astrophysics. Their detection enables us to probe black holes, neutron stars, and the very nature of gravity itself, providing unprecedented insights into the universe. However, detecting GWs presents a formidable technical challenge, given the extreme sensitivity required to measure these faint signals amidst terrestrial noise. The promise of gravitational-wave detection lies not only in transformative scientific discoveries but also in potential spin-offs, including advancements in vibration isolation, precision measurement techniques, and data analysis tools.

This project addressed these challenges by focusing on the design of a cryogenic laser interferometer and a Phase Sensitive OptoMechanical Amplifier (PSOMA). Alongside these technical endeavors, a pilot program was implemented to encourage high school women to explore experimental physics.

Key Findings and Intellectual Merit:

  1. Cryogenic Interferometer Design and Validation:

    • Design Focus: Efforts concentrated on designing a cryogenic interferometer to mitigate thermal noise and improve sensitivity for detecting gravitational waves. Cryogenic cooling significantly reduces the thermal noise that often obscures GW signals.
    • Supporting Experiments: Several critical experiments validated key design aspects, including optimal mirror materials, radiative cooling strategies, and 2-micron laser technology, providing invaluable data to refine the design.
    • Coating Development: Research produced an innovative mirror coating design that improved reflectivity and minimized thermal noise, laying a solid foundation for enhanced interferometer sensitivity.

  2. Phase Sensitive OptoMechanical Amplifier (PSOMA):

    • Control System Development: Developed a control system for PSOMA, which leverages ponderomotive effects to amplify quantum states. This improved our understanding of optomechanical interactions and allowed for better signal amplification.

Broader Impacts:

  1. Pilot Program for Women in Physics:
    The pilot program provided high school women with hands-on experience in gravitational-wave research, encouraging them to consider careers in physics. They gained a foundational understanding of experimental physics while working on practical applications.

  2. Technological Contributions:
    The project made significant contributions to technological frameworks in cryogenic interferometry and phase-sensitive amplification. These advances form a critical foundation for the next generation of gravitational-wave detectors.

  3. Collaborative and Educational Outreach:
    Collaboration among institutions and dissemination of results through workshops, conferences, and publications ensured broad educational impact, benefiting students, researchers, and industry professionals.

Overall, this project advanced the field of cryogenic interferometer design and quantum state amplification, while inspiring broader participation in experimental physics. Its insights will inform future research, fostering more sensitive and accurate gravitational-wave detectors.
